questions.question: What is CSS Box Model?
questions.answer: The CSS Box Model is a fundamental concept that describes how elements are structured. It consists of content, padding, border, and margin. Content is the actual element, padding is space between content and border, border surrounds padding, and margin is space outside the border.

questions.question: Explain the difference between position: relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky
questions.answer: Relative positions relative to normal position, absolute positions relative to nearest positioned ancestor, fixed positions relative to viewport and stays during scroll, sticky toggles between relative and fixed based on scroll position.

questions.question: What is CSS Flexbox?
questions.answer: Flexbox is a one-dimensional layout model that helps in designing flexible responsive layouts without using float or positioning. It provides space distribution between items and powerful alignment capabilities.

questions.question: What is CSS Grid?
questions.answer: CSS Grid is a two-dimensional layout system that can handle both columns and rows. It's designed for laying out larger scale layouts and offers powerful grid-based layout features.

questions.question: What are CSS Selectors?
questions.answer: CSS Selectors are patterns used to select and style HTML elements. Types include element selectors, class selectors, ID selectors, attribute selectors, and pseudo-selectors.

questions.question: What is CSS Specificity?
questions.answer: Specificity is the algorithm used by browsers to determine which CSS rule applies if multiple rules target the same element. It's calculated based on the type of selector used (inline, ID, class, element).

questions.question: What are Media Queries?
questions.answer: Media Queries allow you to apply CSS rules based on device characteristics like screen size, orientation, or resolution. They're fundamental for responsive design.

questions.question: What is the difference between display: none and visibility: hidden?
questions.answer: display: none removes the element from the document flow and hides it, while visibility: hidden keeps the element in the document flow but makes it invisible.

questions.question: What are CSS Preprocessors?
questions.answer: CSS Preprocessors are tools that extend CSS with additional features like variables, nesting, mixins, and functions. Popular examples include Sass, Less, and Stylus.

questions.question: What is the z-index property?
questions.answer: z-index controls the vertical stacking order of elements that overlap. It only works on positioned elements (relative, absolute, fixed, or sticky).

questions.question: What are Pseudo-classes?
questions.answer: Pseudo-classes are keywords that specify a special state of an element, like :hover, :focus, :first-child. They allow you to style elements based on their state or position.

questions.question: What are Pseudo-elements?
questions.answer: Pseudo-elements allow you to style a specific part of an element, like ::before, ::after, ::first-line. They can be used to add cosmetic content.

questions.question: What is the difference between em and rem units?
questions.answer: em is relative to the font-size of its closest parent, while rem is relative to the root element's font-size (html element).

questions.question: What is the CSS Box-sizing property?
questions.answer: Box-sizing defines how the width and height of an element are calculated. border-box includes padding and border in the element's total width and height, while content-box doesn't.

questions.question: What are CSS Variables (Custom Properties)?
questions.answer: CSS Variables are custom property declarations that contain reusable values. They're defined using -- prefix and accessed using var() function.

questions.question: What is CSS BEM methodology?
questions.answer: BEM (Block Element Modifier) is a naming convention for CSS classes to make them more meaningful and maintainable. It structures CSS in terms of blocks, elements, and modifiers.

questions.question: What are CSS Transforms?
questions.answer: CSS Transforms allow you to rotate, scale, skew, or translate elements. They can be 2D or 3D transformations.

questions.question: What are CSS Transitions?
questions.answer: CSS Transitions provide a way to control animation speed when changing CSS properties. They allow property changes to occur smoothly over a specified duration.

questions.question: What is CSS Animation?
questions.answer: CSS Animation allows animation of HTML elements without using JavaScript. It uses @keyframes rule to define the animation sequence.

questions.question: What is the difference between inline and block elements?
questions.answer: Block elements start on a new line and take full width available, while inline elements don't start on a new line and only take up as much width as necessary.

questions.question: What is CSS Float?
questions.answer: Float is a positioning property that places an element to the left or right of its container, allowing text and inline elements to wrap around it.

questions.question: What is Clearfix?
questions.answer: Clearfix is a technique used to ensure that a container element properly contains its floated children by clearing the float.

questions.question: What are CSS Combinators?
questions.answer: Combinators are symbols that explain the relationship between selectors. Common types include descendant (space), child (>), adjacent sibling (+), and general sibling (~).

questions.question: What is CSS Reset?
questions.answer: CSS Reset is a set of CSS rules used to remove browser default styles, ensuring consistent styling across different browsers.

questions.question: What is CSS Normalize?
questions.answer: Normalize.css is a modern alternative to CSS Reset that preserves useful browser defaults rather than removing them, while correcting bugs and common inconsistencies.

questions.question: What are CSS Sprites?
questions.answer: CSS Sprites combine multiple images into a single larger image to reduce HTTP requests. Specific images are displayed by adjusting background-position property.

questions.question: What is CSS Flexbox Gap?
questions.answer: Gap property in Flexbox creates space between flex items without using margin. It provides a more intuitive way to handle spacing in flex layouts.

questions.question: What are CSS Custom Properties (Variables)?
questions.answer: Custom Properties allow you to store values that you can use throughout your stylesheets. They start with -- and are accessed using var() function.

questions.question: What is CSS Grid Auto-Fill vs Auto-Fit?
questions.answer: Auto-fill and auto-fit are grid properties that automatically adjust the number of columns. Auto-fill creates as many columns as possible, while auto-fit collapses empty columns.

questions.question: What is CSS Containment?
questions.answer: CSS Containment is a performance optimization property that tells the browser that an element and its contents are independent of the rest of the document tree.
